Visual Utilities¶

Functions in this file aim at doing visual processing of networkx graph.

lntk.visual_utils._generate_element_list_cytoscape(graph, options=None, verbose=False)[source]¶

Given a graph, this generates a string containing all elements (nodes and edges) ready to be plugged in a javascript call to cytoscape.js

Parameters:
  • graph – a networkx graph
  • options – unused (but might be one day).
  • verbose – If true, the nodes list and the edge list will be printed.

:return a string containing all nodes and edges information

lntk.visual_utils._generate_layout_cytoscape(options)[source]¶
Private function. Generates layout for html file containing network.

:param a dictionnary containing the key “layout”

lntk.visual_utils._generate_stylesheet_cytoscape(G, options)[source]¶

Private function. Handles the style options.

For further information on valid style.

:param G : a networkx graph instance. :param options : a dictionnary indicating the layout and style to apply.

lntk.visual_utils.b64toImage(base64_input)[source]¶

Cast a base 64 encoded unicode string in input to a PIL Image instance. :param base64_input: a base 64 encoded unicode string representing a png image :return: an Image instance from the Pillow library

lntk.visual_utils.graph_sequence_to_gif(output_filename, graph_list, display_config={'layout': 'grid'}, duration=2, tmp_location='')[source]¶
Parameters:
  • output_filename – The git output location
  • graph_list – A list of networkx graph
  • display_config – a dictionnary containing layout and style configuration
  • duration – The duration of each frame where 1 frame = 1 networkx
  • tmp_location – the location in which temporary html and png will be saved. Those should be automatically deleted afterward.
lntk.visual_utils.html_to_png(filepaths, width=1280, height=720, save=False)[source]¶

Takes in input one or a list of paths to html files containing a cytoscape network under variable cy. Returns the base64 of the png of the network.

N.B. Common possible error :
  • (variable cy not found) can be caused by unvalidity of the source of the cytoscape.js in the html file.
Parameters:
  • filepaths – can be one or a list of path to html network files. absolute and relative path are supported.
  • width – the image width
  • height – the image height
  • save – if True, the generated png will be saved in the same directory then its html counterpart.
Returns:

a list of png encoded as base 64 unicode strings
lntk.visual_utils.make_gif_from_filepaths(output_filename, png_filepath_list, duration=2)[source]¶

Given a list of png file path in entry, this function creates a gif showing those png sucessively for a fixed number of time and save it at the given file path.

Parameters:
  • output_filename –
  • png_filepath_list –
  • duration –
Returns:
lntk.visual_utils.make_gif_from_png_base64(output_filename, png_b64_list, duration=2)[source]¶
lntk.visual_utils.networkx_to_cytoscape_html(output_filename, graph, options={'layout': 'grid'}, verbose=False)[source]¶

This functions takes in input a networkx graph and a dictionnary of options and creates a html file containing the graph rendered according to the given options and the cytoscape.js library (i.e. self-contained).

option is a dictionary in which the key ‘layout’ must be present.

N.B. At the current state of implementation, all generated graph are undirected.

Parameters:
  • graph – A networkx graph
  • output_filename – the desired output location
  • options – a dictionnary containing the layout and style options
  • verbose – print extra details if True.
lntk.visual_utils.render_html(file_location)[source]¶

open a Firefox browser with the given graph, returns the selenium browser instance.

lntk.visual_utils.save_png(base64_input, output_file)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • base64 – a base 64 encoded unicode string representing a png image
  • output_file – the path where the image will be saved.
lntk.visual_utils.validate_config(config)[source]¶

Validate that the configuration dictionnary is valid for the cases supported by this program.

See tutorial or source for enumeration of all supported cases (It is quite straigtfoward I promise.)

Parameters:config – a configuration dictionnary (potentially loaded from a json)
